description: Structure, dynamics, and function of biological macromolecules. Properties of macromolecular assemblies, membranes and their compartments. (Formerly, CHEM 450-I).
name: BIOLOGICAL CHEMISTRY I

values.comments:
This course covers the structure, dynamics, and function of biological
macromolecules. The material also includes properties of macromolecular assemblies,
membranes and their compartments.
The course was composed of lectures on basic biochemistry and journal clubs in
which students critically read and discussed papers. Students found the class participation
aspect “a bit distressing,” however. Many called the course “valuable” and “useful” and
commented on the course’s ability to develop students’ skills to think. Students
mentioned learning a lot from this course.
Professor Christianson was “engaging” and “an excellent professor.” Several
students called him “one of the best professors of science” that they had had. Professor
Christianson was able to “convey the key ideas” and was “very willing to help.” He did
cold-call in class, which made students “uncomfortable” and which many found
“distressing.” Nonetheless, many students said that Professor Christianson made the
course a “’must take for majors.”
The class was described as being fairly challenging. The exams were considered a
“bit unorthodox.” Some students liked this, however, since questions were “insightful”
and “challenged [students’] ability to think” about biochemistry as opposed to just
regurgitating information.
